abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is assesses as
            satisfactory as the project substantially achieved its major
            objectives, although realization of the full benefits,
            including those from increased tourism, has been affected
            largely by exogenous factors, principally the effects of the
            breakup of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia. Project
            sustainability is likely given the successful commissioning
            of key project facilities, the Rizana Water Work's
            continued strong operational performance, the resumption of
            growth in the Slovenian economy, improved prospects for the
            revival of tourism, and Slovenia's progress in
            accession within the European Union. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances were satisfactory in all stages of the
            project cycle. The main lessons from the project are: Pay
            particular attention to forecasting water sales in
            environments where macroeconomic and structural reforms are
            being undertaken in view of the impact of the reform on
            industrial restructuring, and consequently, on industrial
            and commercial demand for water. Successful programs for
            reduction of unaccounted-for-water require strong Borrower
            commitment, and a well-designed and well-supported program
            of action. Where the Bank deems it fit to include financial
            performance covenants, it should pay greater attention to
            ensuring effective financial supervision, including
            commitment of the necessary staff and budgetary resources.
